Situation1: They provide in-depth guidance on a critical task where mistakes could have serious consequences.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story: I stood at the edge of the site, clipboard in hand, watching the new guy fumble with the rebar ties. As a mentor, I knew I should step in, walk him through the process, and make sure he understood every step—especially since a mistake here could mean a safety hazard for everyone. My mind raced with the best way to explain the technique, to share the hard-earned lessons I’d gathered over years on the job. But then I caught sight of the notice tacked to the trailer door: an optional training session next week, right in the middle of our busiest period. As a laborer, I was expected to keep pace with the crew, follow every protocol, and not fall behind. If I took time for mentoring or the training, I’d risk slowing the team, maybe even drawing the foreman’s ire. My stomach twisted as I weighed the responsibility to guide the rookie against the pressure to keep my head down and work. The voices of both roles clashed in my mind, each demanding more than I felt I could give.
